conclusion: To determine the pressure of the D ball on the three balls A, B, and C, analyze the forces acting on the system.
Each sphere has a mass m and therefore a weight mg (where g is the acceleration due to gravity).
The D ball is in equilibrium, meaning the net force acting on it is zero.
The centers of the four spheres form a tetrahedron.
The centers of the three bottom spheres (A, B, and C) form an equilateral triangle.
The center of the D ball is directly above the centroid of the triangle formed by A, B, and C.
The weight of the D ball is mg.
The weight is distributed equally among the three bottom spheres (A, B, and C) because the system is symmetric.
Each bottom sphere supports one-third of the weight of the D ball.
The force exerted by the D ball on each of the bottom spheres is mg/3.
Pressure is defined as force per unit area.
The contact area between the D ball and each of the bottom spheres is a circle with radius r.
The area of contact is πr^2.
The pressure P exerted by the D ball on each bottom sphere is P = (mg/3) / (πr^2).
The pressure of the D ball on each of the three bottom spheres (A, B, and C) is P = mg/(3πr^2).
